title: Relative Clauses - Which, That or Nothing 1
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2 or wherever it is possible B1nothingB2.

sentence: I'm reading now is by Thomas Pynchon.
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. There's a pronoun 'I' after the relative pronoun, so it's not the subject of the relative clause, so we can leave it out.
Corr: which, that or nothing. There's a pronoun 'you' after the relative pronoun, so it's not the subject of the relative clause, so we can leave it out.
Corr: which or that. We cannot leave out the relative pronoun because it's the subject of the relative clause. As there's 'anything' in the sentence, 'that' is a better solution than 'which'.

sentence: You need to read the books without
explain: Corr: which. As there's a preposition, we cannot leave out the relative pronoun and it cannot be 'that' because we cannot use it after prepositions.

sentence: Why do I always have to do the tasks
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. We can leave out the relative pronoun because 'others' is the subject of the relative clause.

sentence: I didn't know any of the films
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. Here it's possible to leave out the relative pronoun because the subject of the relative clause is 'they'.

sentence: I can't solve the problems with
my kids bother me all the time.
explain: Corr: which. As there's a preposition, we cannot leave out the relative pronoun and it cannot be 'that' because we cannot use it after prepositions.

sentence: scratched my daughter's hand is my favourite one.
explain: Corr: which or that. Here we cannot leave out the relative pronoun because because it's the subject of the relative clause.

sentence: I'd like to choose a hotel
is near the city centre, but not too expensive.
explain: Corr: which or that. Here we cannot leave out the relative pronoun because because it's the subject of the relative clause.
Corr: which. As there's a preposition (from), we cannot leave out the relative pronoun and it cannot be 'that' because we cannot use it after prepositions.
